title: The History and Practice of Hypnotic Fascination
first_phrase: In the preceding text, we learn how James Braid, a Manchester physician who was a skeptic of mesmerism, witnessed a mesmerist named Lafontaine in England in 1911. Despite his skepticism, Braid became interested in the subject and conducted his own research. In the last 200 words, the text explores the limitations of modern hypnotherapy, which focuses only on a limited range of phenomena and neglects other aspects of mesmerism. Specifically, the text highlights the technique of fascination as being overlooked in favor of easier, less effective methods. The text also mentions the rare state of hypnotic fascination, which is difficult to induce but has been described in literature by travelers to India and other parts of Europe.

Questo atteggiamento oltre che ad una percentuale di successi inferiori ai metodi precedenti15, ha portato a relegare le altre fenomenologie originariamente connesse al magnetismo ad un'analisi sommaria. La metodica della fascinazione, che domanda invece a chi la vuole praticare un notevole lavoro preparatorio ed un approccio alle basi del cosiddetto “magnetismo”, è così stata spesso tralasciata in favore di altri metodi magari più facili da applicare, ma sicuramente meno efficaci.16 Nella letteratura, soprattutto del secolo scorso, si parla ogni tanto di fascinazione ipnotica. Non è tuttavia uno stato frequentemente descritto, in quanto sono poche le persone in grado di provocarlo efficacemente. I racconti vengono da viaggiatori in India, anche se pure in Europa si parla di ciò.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the method of fascination in hypnosis, which requires extensive preparation and a connection to the basics of magnetism, has been overlooked in favor of easier but less effective methods. Despite being less commonly described, hypnotic fascination is a powerful state that can be achieved by few individuals. It's important to note that simpler methods should be learned first before attempting more complex techniques.
